channel.title: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?
channel.description:
My school is annoying as hell. All the computers default to IE on restart, or logout. So every time I have to log in, open chrome, set as default, and all that. So is there a way I could make a shortcut that opens to a specific page, with chrome only?
Oh, and I have epic bot. Is there a way to force safe mode without hitting 's' during load?

item.title: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:19, topic:491653”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=609887.msg4241506#msg4241506 date=1361846921]

So am I just a lucky bastard that managed to hack my entire student user database to admin privileges and get away with it? Before you say it I had to create a batch file on a thumb drive at home so that I could access the terminal at school. They ran WinXP and a shitty security system that didn’t monitor anything flooding the command prompt or even that it was opened. It only blocked the making of batch files and trying to run it from start menu. I did however get caught with a batch file on my username and suspended for 2 days. The rest was never figured out.

@OP - Its not going to happen at all. Unless you make them a list of security flaws of IE that Chrome doesn’t have, best you’ll get is default for everyone.

What would be the downside of chrome being default for everyone?
You all make it seem like such a bad thing.
[/quote]
It is a bad thing for schools because it didn’t come built into the OS, thats why they wont change. Thats the reason every school I’ve been to gave me. Even though each teacher I’ve talked to about it has a pendrive with Opera, Firefox, or Chrome installed. Its not a bad thing to people who actually know. Just remember, most school boards (aka old people who don’t actually know a ton about technology) think that just because it is built into the OS, it means it is far more secure than any other you can download.[/quote]
The IT department at my district makes it mandatory that FireFox, Chrome, and IE are installed (obviously IE is), but they still default to using IE…

Read full topic
item.source: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?

So am I just a lucky bastard that managed to hack my entire student user database to admin privileges and get away with it? Before you say it I had to create a batch file on a thumb drive at home so that I could access the terminal at school. They ran WinXP and a shitty security system that didn’t monitor anything flooding the command prompt or even that it was opened. It only blocked the making of batch files and trying to run it from start menu. I did however get caught with a batch file on my username and suspended for 2 days. The rest was never figured out.

@OP - Its not going to happen at all. Unless you make them a list of security flaws of IE that Chrome doesn’t have, best you’ll get is default for everyone.
[/quote]
What would be the downside of chrome being default for everyone?
You all make it seem like such a bad thing.[/quote]
It is a bad thing for schools because it didn’t come built into the OS, thats why they wont change. Thats the reason every school I’ve been to gave me. Even though each teacher I’ve talked to about it has a pendrive with Opera, Firefox, or Chrome installed. Its not a bad thing to people who actually know. Just remember, most school boards (aka old people who don’t actually know a ton about technology) think that just because it is built into the OS, it means it is far more secure than any other you can download.

item.source: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?

item.title: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Andrew Ferguson:

I’d just say to suck it up and deal with it, schools always over react when you mess with their computers. I’ve even got felony charges in the past for installing Halo 2 on the computers in our computer lab. Apparently I was “promoting terrorism on government property”, but yet, don’t mess with the computers, schools these days are poor as shit and will do anything to make some extra money.

Haha, similar story, installed a cracked version of photoshop and I got called into the headteacher’s office and threatened with a half a million pound fine, they said they were close to calling the police… Was banned permanently from using computers after that.

At topic, I doubt the network admin can just set it up so you can explicitly have chrome as default, the way it worked in my school, the appdata folder was wiped every time the user logged out. If he were to do it, he would most likely have to make every one using the system with chrome as default.

Read full topic

Well, at my CTS, I got Halo installed and all that. But that’s because it’s not a normal school, and the funding we receive is way better than public schools. But of course it’s the public school that’s an issue

item.source: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?

item.title: Making a hyperlink open in different browsers?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Cruel Truth:

It sounds like the computers are being reset every 24 hours. Due to this there is no real way of stopping it.

I know there’s a way you can make a shortcut start in one place. But they made the home page for chrome one of the school sites >.>

Fridder:

Sounds like your school is using Deep Freeze. You really can’t do anything unless you know the deepfreeze username and password. Control + shift + alt + F6 opens the deepfreeze menu.

Tried that at school. Didn’t work.

Read full topic

@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Fridder:

Sounds like your school is using Deep Freeze. You really can’t do anything unless you know the deepfreeze username and password. Control + shift + alt + F6 opens the deepfreeze menu.

My school uses iboss for internet security. and some n network shit for the computers.
I don’t know what the hell they were thinking. They made it possible for 4 computers to run on 1 tower. That’s by far the stupidest thing they could do, seeing as the computers have 2gbs ram max, each.
